entries.name: Age
entries: Humans reach adulthood in their late teens and live less than a century.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Humans tend toward no particular alignment. The best and the worst are found among them.

entries.name: Size
entries: Humans vary widely in height and build, from barely 5 feet to well over 6 feet tall. Regardless of your position in that range, your size is Medium.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and one extra language of your choice. Humans typically learn the languages of other peoples they deal with, including obscure dialects. They are fond of sprinkling their speech with words borrowed from other tongues: Orc curses, Elvish musical expressions, Dwarvish military phrases, and so on.

entries.name: Electric Blood
entries: You have resistance to lightning damage.

entries.name: Fury of the Storm
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can use your action to unleash the divine energy within yourself, causing your eyes to glimmer and lightning to crackle around you.

Your transformation lasts for 1 minute or until you end it as a bonus action. During it you can add your Strength modifier twice to Strength Checks and Strength Saving Throws. Your weapon attacks deal additional lightning damage equal to your proficiency bonus on a hit.
Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Divine Lightning
entries: You know the {@spell lightning lure|TCE} cantrip. In addition, once you reach level 5, once per day you can cast {@spell lightning arrow}, Constitution is your spellcasting modifer for those spells. If you have the Spellcasting or the Pact Magic class feature, thess spells are added to the spell list of your spellcasting class.

entries.name: Æsir Marks
entries: An elf manipulates a lord into giving him more fortune than what he should, a warrior unleashes a thunderstorm around him, a huntress spots an ambush designed to kill her. Each of these people possesses a Afsir mark, markings etched on the skin in vivid colors, magical power made flesh.
Possessors of an /Esir Mark are powerful mortals, often given important position in tribes and cities, when they are not living on the fringes of society, set on goals only they understand.

It is said that those Marks are tied to an ancestry from Norse gods, also known as Aesir, intertwining their bloodlines with that of mortals. Powers came from such unions, profoundly altering the life of those it touched.
A Mark manifests in a person around adolescence, as streaks of paint like pigments appear over their body, though not every heir manifests the mark.

entries.name: The Mark of Thor
entries: {@note I'm telling you, I've never seen anyone fiercer on the battlefield than them, it was a slaughter.}
{@bold - A scared soldier}

entries.name: Thor, Champion of Asgard
entries: Thor (Old Norse: Porr) is the god of thunder and lightning, associated with strength, storms, hallowing and fertility. He is the son of Odin and Jord, the personification of the Earth, and is physically the strongest of the Æsir. Thor is described as being fierce eyed, with red hair and a full beard, and he is quick to anger and has an enormous appetite. His excursions out of his realm have lead him to meet humans that he felt an affinity for, blessing their bloodline with his Mark.

entries.name: Age
entries: Humans reach adulthood in their late teens and live less than a century.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Humans tend toward no particular alignment. The best and the worst are found among them.

entries.name: Size
entries: Humans vary widely in height and build, from barely 5 feet to well over 6 feet tall. Regardless of your position in that range, your size is Medium.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and one extra language of your choice. Humans typically learn the languages of other peoples they deal with, including obscure dialects. They are fond of sprinkling their speech with words borrowed from other tongues: Orc curses, Elvish musical expressions, Dwarvish military phrases, and so on.

entries.name: Blindsight
entries: You have blindsight to a range of 10ft.

entries.name: Godly Hands
entries: You gain proficiency in Dexterity Checks ({@skill Sleight of hand}) and with 2 {@item artisan's tools|phb} of your choice. Whenever you make a check with any of these proficiencies you can add a d4 to the roll

entries.name: Betrayed
entries: You have have advantage on Wisdom (Insight) checks to determine if someone is lying to you or trying to betray you.

entries.name: Æsir Marks
entries: An elf manipulates a lord into giving him more fortune than what he should, a warrior unleashes a thunderstorm around him, a huntress spots an ambush designed to kill her. Each of these people possesses a Afsir mark, markings etched on the skin in vivid colors, magical power made flesh.
Possessors of an Æsir Mark are powerful mortals, often given important position in tribes and cities, when they are not living on the fringes of society, set on goals only they understand.

It is said that those Marks are tied to an ancestry from Norse gods, also known as Aesir, intertwining their bloodlines with that of mortals. Powers came from such unions, profoundly altering the life of those it touched.
A Mark manifests in a person around adolescence, as streaks of paint like pigments appear over their body, though not every heir manifests the mark.

entries.name: The Mark of Hod
entries: {@note It's like he was reading me like a parchment, how did he know I was lying, i'm supposed to be good at it.}
{@bold - A shocked burglar}

entries.name: Hod, Blind and Betrayed
entries: Hod is a blind god and a son of Odin and Frigg in Norse mythology. Tricked and guided by Loki, he shot the mistletoe arrow which was to slay the otherwise invulnerable Baldr. Legend says that he was then slain by the gods. But perhaps he survived, and his powers manifest still in his descendants. He is blind, but the gods would desire that no occasion should rise of naming this god, for the work of his hands shall long be held in memory among gods and men.

entries.name: Age
entries: Although elves reach physical maturity at about the same age as humans, the elven understanding of adulthood goes beyond physical growth to encompass worldly experience. An elf typically claims adulthood and an adult name around the age of 100 and can live to be 750 years old.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Elves love freedom, variety, and self-expression, so they lean strongly toward the gentler aspects of chaos. They value and protect others' freedom as well as their own, and they are more often good than not.

entries.name: Size
entries: Elves range from under 5 to over 6 feet tall and have slender builds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to twilit forests and the night sky, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Keen Senses
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Perception} skill.

entries.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and magic can't put you to sleep.

entries.name: Trance
entries: Elves don't need to sleep. Instead, they meditate deeply, remaining semiconscious, for 4 hours a day. (The Common word for such meditation is "trance.") While meditating, you can dream after a fashion; such dreams are actually mental exercises that have become reflexive through years of practice. After resting in this way, you gain the same benefit that a human does from 8 hours of sleep.
{@note If you meditate during a long rest, you finish the rest after only 4 hours. You otherwise obey all the rules for a long rest; only the duration is changed.}

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Elvish. Elvish is fluid, with subtle intonations and intricate grammar. Elven literature is rich and varied, and their songs and poems are famous among other races. Many bards learn their language so they can add Elvish ballads to their repertoires.

entries.name: Trickster's Magic
entries: You know the {@spell Vicious mockery} cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell Charm person} spell once as a 2nd-level spell. Once you reach 5th level you can also cast the {@spell Suggestion} spell once. You must finish a long rest to cast these spells again with this trait. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.
If you have the Spellcasting or the Pact Magic class feature, these spells are added to the spell list of your spellcasting class.

entries.name: Schemer's Disguise
entries: Once per short rest you can cast the spell {@spell Disguise self}, targeting yourself only.

entries.name: Æsir Marks
entries: An elf manipulates a lord into giving him more fortune than what he should, a warrior unleashes a thunderstorm around him, a huntress spots an ambush designed to kill her. Each of these people possesses a Afsir mark, markings etched on the skin in vivid colors, magical power made flesh.
Possessors of an Æsir Mark are powerful mortals, often given important position in tribes and cities, when they are not living on the fringes of society, set on goals only they understand.

It is said that those Marks are tied to an ancestry from Norse gods, also known as Aesir, intertwining their bloodlines with that of mortals. Powers came from such unions, profoundly altering the life of those it touched.
A Mark manifests in a person around adolescence, as streaks of paint like pigments appear over their body, though not every heir manifests the mark.

entries.name: The Mark of Loki
entries: {@note How can you accuse your own grandmother of stealing your purse ? You probably lost it and can't remember.}
{@bold - A disappointed friend}

entries.name: Loki: Trickster and Schemer
entries: Loki, in Norse mythology, a cunning trickster who had the ability to change his shape and sex. Although his father was the giant Farbauti, he was included among the Aesir He was the principal cause of the death of the god Balder. Loki was bound to a rock as punishment. He is also father to many monstrous creatures said to cause the advent of Ragnarok. His descendants are known to also cause discord and dissent among the people they meet.

entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Elvish. Elvish is fluid, with subtle intonations and intricate grammar. Elven literature is rich and varied, and their songs and poems are famous among other races. Many bards learn their language so they can add Elvish ballads to their repertoires.

entries.name: Primal Understanding
entries: You can cast the {@spell animal friendship} and {@spell speak with animals} spells with this trait, requiring no material component. Once you cast either spell with this trait, you can't cast that spell with it again until you finish a short or long rest. The ability you increased with this subclass is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Inherited Wisdom
entries: You gain proficiency in two of the following skills: {@skill Nature}, {@skill Medicine}, {@skill Arcana}, {@skill Animal handling}.

entries.name: Æsir Marks
entries: An elf manipulates a lord into giving him more fortune than what he should, a warrior unleashes a thunderstorm around him, a huntress spots an ambush designed to kill her. Each of these people possesses a Afsir mark, markings etched on the skin in vivid colors, magical power made flesh.
Possessors of an Æsir Mark are powerful mortals, often given important position in tribes and cities, when they are not living on the fringes of society, set on goals only they understand.

It is said that those Marks are tied to an ancestry from Norse gods, also known as Aesir, intertwining their bloodlines with that of mortals. Powers came from such unions, profoundly altering the life of those it touched.
A Mark manifests in a person around adolescence, as streaks of paint like pigments appear over their body, though not every heir manifests the mark.

entries.name: The Mark of Freyja
entries: {@note I'm telling you, she did some magic stuff, next thing you know my herd was fertile, I know a good omen when I see one.}
{@bold - A thankful farmer}

entries.name: Freyja: Love, Fertility and Death
entries: Freyja ("Lady"), most renowned of the Norse goddesses, who was in charge of love, fertility, battle, and death. Her father was Njord, the sea god. Pigs were sacred to her, and she rode a boar with golden bristles. A chariot drawn by cats was another of her vehicles. Greedy and lascivious, Freyja was also credited with the evil act of teaching witchcraft to the Aesir. Legend says that Freyja traveled through the world seeking a lost husband and weeping tears of gold Her descendants are often sages amongst their village.

entries.name: Age
entries: Dwarves mature at the same rate as humans, but they're considered young until they reach the age of 50. On average, they live about 350 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Most dwarves are lawful, believing firmly in the benefits of a well-ordered society. They tend toward good as well, with a strong sense of fair play and a belief that everyone deserves to share in the benefits of a just order.

entries.name: Size
entries: Dwarves stand between 4 and 5 feet tall and average about 150 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your speed is not reduced by wearing heavy armor.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Dwarven Resilience
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage.

entries.name: Dwarven Combat Training
entries: You have proficiency with the {@item battleaxe|phb}, {@item handaxe|phb}, {@item light hammer|phb}, and {@item warhammer|phb}.

entries.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with the artisan's tools of your choice: {@item Smith's tools|phb}, {@item brewer's supplies|phb}, or {@item mason's tools|phb}.

entries.name: Stonecunning
entries: Whenever you make an Intelligence ({@skill History}) check related to the origin of stonework, you are considered proficient in the {@skill History} skill and add double your proficiency bonus to the check, instead of your normal proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Dwarvish. Dwarvish is full of hard consonants and guttural sounds, and those characteristics spill over into whatever other language a dwarf might speak.

entries.name: Thoughtful Justice
entries: When you make a Wisdom (Insight) check you can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to the ability check.

entries.name: Forged by War
entries: Bludgeoning, slashing and piercing damage you take from non-magical weapons is reduced by 1.

entries.name: Lawful Protection
entries: Once per long rest if a creature you can see within 60 feet of you takes damage, you can use your reaction to reduce that damage by {@dice 2d10} and take that amount of damage instead

entries.name: Æsir Marks
entries: An elf manipulates a lord into giving him more fortune than what he should, a warrior unleashes a thunderstorm around him, a huntress spots an ambush designed to kill her. Each of these people possesses a Afsir mark, markings etched on the skin in vivid colors, magical power made flesh.
Possessors of an Æsir Mark are powerful mortals, often given important position in tribes and cities, when they are not living on the fringes of society, set on goals only they understand.

It is said that those Marks are tied to an ancestry from Norse gods, also known as Aesir, intertwining their bloodlines with that of mortals. Powers came from such unions, profoundly altering the life of those it touched.
A Mark manifests in a person around adolescence, as streaks of paint like pigments appear over their body, though not every heir manifests the mark.

entries.name: The Mark of Tyr
entries: {@note Glad to have them dwarfs with us, you know they won't betray us, but I wouldn't want to be the one lying to them.}
{@bold - A war veteran}

entries.name: Tyr: Justice, Law and War
entries: Tyr was the Norse god of war, a brave warrior and member of the Aesir tribe, he championed order and justice. He lost his arm to Loki's ferocious offspring Fenrir, the giant wolf. The one-armed god of the Norse pantheon, Tyr was represented war and bloodshed Yetn he was also known as a bringer of justice and order. Those bearing his mark represent that duality, fierce in battle but also fair in their judgment.

entries: Dwarves mature at the same rate as humans, but they're considered young until they reach the age of 50. On average, they live about 350 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Most dwarves are lawful, believing firmly in the benefits of a well-ordered society. They tend toward good as well, with a strong sense of fair play and a belief that everyone deserves to share in the benefits of a just order.

entries.name: Size
entries: Dwarves stand between 4 and 5 feet tall and average about 150 pounds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Speed
entries: Your speed is not reduced by wearing heavy armor.

entries: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

entries.name: Dwarven Resilience
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage.

entries.name: Dwarven Combat Training
entries: You have proficiency with the {@item battleaxe|phb}, {@item handaxe|phb}, {@item light hammer|phb}, and {@item warhammer|phb}.

entries.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency with the artisan's tools of your choice: {@item Smith's tools|phb}, {@item brewer's supplies|phb}, or {@item mason's tools|phb}.

entries.name: Stonecunning
entries: Whenever you make an Intelligence ({@skill History}) check related to the origin of stonework, you are considered proficient in the {@skill History} skill and add double your proficiency bonus to the check, instead of your normal proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Dwarvish. Dwarvish is full of hard consonants and guttural sounds, and those characteristics spill over into whatever other language a dwarf might speak.

entries.name: Ice Body
entries: You have resistance to cold damage and ignore exhaustion caused by cold environnements.

entries.name: Primordial Toughness
entries: While not wearing any armour your AC is equal to 13 + your Dexterity Modifier. You can equip a shield and still retain this benefit.

entries.name: Stupendous Might
entries: When you make a Strength (Athletics) check you can roll a d4 and add the number rolled to the ability check.

entries.name: Æsir Marks
entries: An elf manipulates a lord into giving him more fortune than what he should, a warrior unleashes a thunderstorm around him, a huntress spots an ambush designed to kill her. Each of these people possesses a Afsir mark, markings etched on the skin in vivid colors, magical power made flesh.
Possessors of an Æsir Mark are powerful mortals, often given important position in tribes and cities, when they are not living on the fringes of society, set on goals only they understand.

It is said that those Marks are tied to an ancestry from Norse gods, also known as Aesir, intertwining their bloodlines with that of mortals. Powers came from such unions, profoundly altering the life of those it touched.
A Mark manifests in a person around adolescence, as streaks of paint like pigments appear over their body, though not every heir manifests the mark.

entries.name: Corrupted Mark: The Mark of Ymir
entries: Where most of the Aesir have left their mark on a race, there is another mark. Much less known, and often hidden because of the stigma it carries.

Ymir the first giant was slain, but his essence didn't leave the world, tainting it instead Many dwarves were affected by it, and their descendants bear this distinctive mark. It grants many powers, but also brings shame to families, shunning away their child bearing the mark.

entries.name: Ymir: Primordial Giant
entries: Ymir is the personification of the chaos before creation. Ymir had great power over the element of ice, which was what its Jotnar children inherited from him. He was tremendously durable and strong, being able to fight alone against the Aesir.

entries.name: Age
entries: Jötunnkyn reach adulthood at age 14 and live up to 160 years. But many die younger due to the harsh environment.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Jötunnkyn live on the fringes of society, where they value self-sufficiency and hunting. They are generally neutral, organizing in tribes under charismatic and powerful leaders.

entries.name: Hunter at Heart
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Survival} skill

entries.name: Thick Skin
entries: You gain resistance to cold damage and ignore penalties imposed by cold climate

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read and write Common and Primordial

Jotnar (plural of Jotunn) are creatures that share a bloodline a to the primordial being Ymir, having been born from his sweat. Jotnar predate all of the Aesir (Norse gods) and some, like Odin, are descendants of Jotnar.
Their descendant, also called Jotunnkyn, live in the northernmost edges of the world a place regarded to be dark, foreboding, where winter never ceases.

They live a life of tough survival and endurance in the unforgiving lands that host them, they've grown accustomed to this harsh lifestyle. Their lives are spent in veneration of their Forefather, blood sacrifices of fallen beast they've hunted are common practice in their culture.

{@bold Appearance:} They look humanoid, although they are much taller and larger than the average human. Their skin has a blue tint to it, reflecting their ancestral blood. Many bear horns, goat-like in appearence, protruding from the side of their skull Their eyes are pupil-less and unicolor.

entries.name: Age
entries: Odinsons reach adulthood at age 18 and live up to 210 years. But many die younger due to enemies they make.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Odinsons live in many societies, where they live lives governed by self-interest and wisdom. They are neutral, organizing themselves across many professions.

entries.name: Battle Foresight
entries: You catch glimpses of the future in battle, you can add {@dice 1d6} to your initiative checks.

entries.name: Divine Ways
entries: You have advantage on Animal handling (Wisdom) checks involving wolves, and on Performance (Charisma) checks made using poetry.

entries.name: Lost Vision
entries: Odin gave up one of his eyes for wisdom, and his descendants all have a nonfunctional eye. You have disadvantage on perception checks relying on sight.

entries.name: Odin's Magic
entries: You know the {@spell guidance} cantrip. Once you reach 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell find familiar} spell once without requiring material components (raven form only). Once you reach 5th level, you can also cast the {@spell augury} spell once. You must finish a long rest to cast these spells again with this trait. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read and write Common and 3 other languages of your choice (reflecting the society you grew up in).

Odin is the ruler of the Aesir tribe of deities, yet he often ventures far from their kingdom, Asgard, on long, solitary wanderings throughout the cosmos on purely self-interested quests. He's a relentless seeker after and giver of wisdom, but he has little regard for communal values such as justice, fairness, or respect for law and convention. He's the divine patron of rulers, and also of outlaws.
He left his mark on humans, blessing those he judged worthy. Those blessings extended to their descendants, creating the Odinsons.

Odinsons live in societies where humans were present. Creating enemies or building governments, their interests vary greatly between individuals, but what unites them is their great wisdom and ruthless pursuit of knowledge.

{@bold Appearance:} They look human, but upon closer inspection one of their eye is pupil-less and blind Many bear tattoo-like- like runes on their skin, representing their ancestral connection to the Aesir.

optionalfeature.name: Consecration of the sea
entries: Consecrations are a trait that you can give to your half-orc character, it replaces the Savage Attack trait.
{@bold Effect:} Your movements are fluid like the ocean, you have a swim speed equal to your walking speed In addition attacks of opportunity against you are made at disadvantage.

optionalfeature.name: Consecration of the storm
entries: Consecrations are a trait that you can give to your half-orc character, it replaces the Savage Attack trait.
{@bold Effect:} if you use the Dash Action, clouds carry you, you can gain a flying speed equal to your walking speed until the end of your turn, where you fall if nothing is holding you aloft.

optionalfeature.name: Consecration of the grove
entries: Consecrations are a trait that you can give to your half-orc character, it replaces the Savage Attack trait.

{@bold Effect:}  as a bonus action, a vine sprouts from your back, allowing you to attempt to grab a Huge or smaller creature within 30ft of you, and pull it closer to you. It must succeed a Strength saving throw (Save DC: 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier.) or be pulled in a space adjacent to yours. You can use this ability a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus per long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Consecration of the earth
entries: Consecrations are a trait that you can give to your half-orc character, it replaces the Savage Attack trait.

{@bold Effect:} As a reaction, you cover your body with stone, diminishing incoming damage. Roll {@dice 1d12} and substract the number rolled to the damage. You can use this ability a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus per long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Consecration of the night
entries: Consecrations are a trait that you can give to your half-orc character, it replaces the Savage Attack trait.
{@bold Effect:} You can see normally in darkness, both magical and nonmagical, to a distance of 90 feet.

optionalfeature.name: Consecration of the dawn
entries: Consecrations are a trait that you can give to your half-orc character, it replaces the Savage Attack trait.
{@bold Effect:} You have resistance to radiant and fire damage.

optionalfeature.name: Consecration of the dusk
entries: Consecrations are a trait that you can give to your half-orc character, it replaces the Savage Attack trait.

{@bold Effect:} As a bonus action, you vanish in a cloud of darkness, you teleport up to 20 feet to an unoccupied space that you can see. You can use this ability a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus per long rest.

optionalfeature.name: Consecration of the dusk
entries: Consecrations are a trait that you can give to your half-orc character, it replaces the Savage Attack trait.
{@bold Effect:} You have resistance against Charm effects and when a creature recovers from being charmed by you, it has no memory of what happened during the time it was charmed.
The old warrior stood in front of the crowd raising his stump as they all fell silent. "Tyr sacrificed his hand to save the gods", he yells to the young warriors in front of him.

"We, the law bringers, must do the same, justice and law costs, even when it takes away a part of you! May the One- Handed god protect you all" he says as his limb drops and t gruesome sacrifice takes place. Some scream, some grunt, b all have a burning desire in their eyes, to become a warrior Tyr. AH of the young warriors bring down their weapons ai hands fall to the ground.

A bloody sacrifice in order to prove to the world that thes men and women put justice and law above anything else. "ARISE, LAW BRINGERS, ARISE, WARRIORS OF TYR!" he shouts, rattling their bones as if Tyr himself was calling them.

subclassFeature.name: Restriction: Ritual Sacrifice
entries: All that take the path of Tyr, sacrifice their hand to prove that they will always keep a promise like their god and will pursue justice and law, even at the cost of their lives. In exchange, they can wield 2 handed weapons with one hand, losing the benefit if they regrow the limb or another hand.

subclassFeature.name: Eye for an Eye
entries: Starting at level 3, You can choose to take more pain to inflict more pain. While raging, when an enemy damages you with melee attack that deals piercing, slashing or bludgeoning damage, you can choose to let the damage bypass your resistance. If you do so, you can, in retaliation, use your reaction to make a single melee weapon attack against them.

subclassFeature.name: Embodiment of Law
entries: At level 6, You become proficient in {@skill Insight} if you are not already. In addition you have advantage on Insight checks, and can use Insight (Constitution) checks instead of Insight (Wisdom) checks for them, using your body as your guide.
In addition, once per turn when you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for an attack you make with a melee weapon, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1 or a 2.

subclassFeature.name: Embodiment of Justice
entries: At level 10, while raging, you can force justice to shine through. You can cast the {@spell compelled duel} spell at will, your rage doesn't prevent the casting or the concentration on this spell.

subclassFeature.name: Embodiment of War
entries: At level 14, you are shattering the battlefield. While raging, w once per turn, when you miss with a melee weapon attack, you can reroll the attack roll.

subclassFeature.name: College of the Hearth
entries: {@note One may have a blazing hearth in one's soul and yet no one ever came to sit by it. Passers-by see only a wisp of smoke from the chimney and continue on their way.}

Bards of the college of the hearth have their origin rooted in the north, where the cold winters and harsh environment is breaking down the moral of everyone. They come with their songs about joy and warmth, family and happiness, giving a new smile and hope to the downtrodden and the lost.

subclassFeature.name: Poignant Hope
entries: Your tales bolster the moral of the broken and the downed. Beginning at 3rd level, when a creature rolls a 1 using one of your Bardic Inspiration dice, they can reroll the dice until the result is different from a 1. At 5th level, they can reroll a 1 or 2 until they get a different result, at 10th level, they can reroll a 1, 2 or 3. Finally, at 15th level they can reroll a 1, 2, 3 or 4.

subclassFeature.name: Endurance of the Hearth
entries: At 3rd level, the warmth that you bring washes away the fatigue from the journey. When a creature adds one of your Bardic Inspiration dice, they can remove one point of exhaustion. You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Fire in the Heart
entries: Upon reaching 6th level, you can take one minute to sing about the strength your companions brought from home. Choose up to 8 creatures, they gain advantage on ability checks using skills that they are proficient in, for the next hour. You can use this ability a number of times equal to half your Charisma modifier (rounded up), and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Protective Shelter
entries: Beginning at level 6, you learn the {@spell magic circle} spell, it counts as bard spell for you but doesn't count against the number of bard spells you know. A delightful warmth reigns inside the circle when you cast it.

In addition you can cast this spell at its lowest level without expending a spell slot, as an action without providing any material component. You must complete a long rest before using this ability again.

subclassFeature.name: Lingering Memories of Home
entries: At 14th level, when a companion adds one of your Bardic Inspiration dice, the tale stays stuck in their mind and brings them comfort. They can keep the inspiration dice for up to 8 hours instead of 10 minutes. In addition while holding on to the dice, a creature is immune to fear.

subclassFeature.name: Arctic Domain
entries: {@note An arrow flies through the air, silence, the noise of frost breaking. The enemy recoils in fear, the allied soldier laughs and jumps back into the fray. The cleric keeps chanting as another layer of ice surrounds his allies, protecting them.}
Cleric of the Arctic domain channel the power of the unyielding winter. Where many fear the bite of the arctic, they embrace it and use it to protect their loved ones from harm.

entries.caption: Arctic Domain Spells
rows: {@spell cone of cold}, {@spell circle of power}

subclassFeature.name: Winter's Protection
entries: At level 1, you know the {@spell armor of agathys} spell, it becomes a cleric spell for you, it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day and you always have it prepared.

When you cast this spell using a spell slot level of up to half your cleric level (rounded up), the temporary HP and damage dealt by the spell increases by a number equal to half your Wisdom Modifier and the range becomes touch instead of self.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiency
entries: Also at 1st level, you gain proficiency with heavy armor.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Ice prison
entries: Starting at 2nd level, as an action, you can brandish your holy symbol, facing a creature you can see within 30ft of you. It must make a Strength saving throw or the ice forming around it will encase it for 1 minute.

While encased in this way a creature is {@condition incapacitated} and its speed becomes 0, it is also immune to all damage while trapped. At the end of each of its turn it can try to repeat the Strength saving throw, breaking free of the ice on a success.

subclassFeature.name: Glacial Soul
entries: At 6th level, the divine ice shines through you:

items: You learn the {@spell ray of frost} cantrip, it counts as a cleric cantrip for you.
When you deal cold damage to a creature, you can also reduce its movement speed by 10 ft. until the start of your next turn.
You gain resistance to cold damage.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: Starting at 8th level, you add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any cleric cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Herald of the Arctic
entries: Starting at 17th level, your blessed affinity with the cold is unmatched:

items: You gain immunity to cold damage.

You can use your action to activate an aura of Blizzard in a 30ft radius around you that lasts for 1 minute or until you dismiss it using another action. You and your allies within that radius are considered heavily obscured to others.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Aurora
entries: Druids of the aurora hail from the northern frozen regions, accustomed to the dire cold and dark nights, they grew fond of it, for only in those dark hours could you truly see the beauty of the aurora borealis. This wonder of nature guides those druids, its light shining through them. They are known to use the northern lights to charm recalcitrant creatures, and intend to bring the beauty of this light across the Realms.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Your connection to the aurora borealis grants you access to certain spells. At 2nd level, you learn the {@spell Sacred flame} cantrip. At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to the spells listed for that level in the Circle of the Aurora Spells table.
Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day.

subclassFeature.name: Mesmerising Light
entries: At 2nd level, as a bonus action you can attempt to charm an enemy within 60ft of you with the beauty of the aurora. The creature must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature becomes {@condition charmed} until the end of your next turn. While Charmed by this feature, the creature is Incapacitated and has a speed of 0. The effect ends early the creature takes takes any damage.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Embodiment of the Frozen Light
entries: At 2nd level, as an action, you can expend a use of your Wild Shape feature to let the aurora shine through you, rather than transforming into a beast form, you gain the following benefits:

items: Your form, just like the aurora, becomes fleeting, making it hard to discern you, you can add your Wisdom Modifier to your AC.
Your speed increases by 10ft.
Once per turn if you deal radiant or cold damage you can add your Wisdom Modifier to one damage roll.

entries: Those effects end after 10 minutes, or immediately if you don or wear medium, heavy armor, a shield, or are {@condition incapacitated}. (You cannot benefit from this feature if you already add your Wisdom Modifier to your AC).

subclassFeature.name: Beguiling Aurora
entries: Starting at 6th level, you get advantage on saving throws against charm effects.
In addition your spells and abilities ignore immunity to the charmed condition and instead those creatures have advantage on saving throws against your charm effects.

subclassFeature.name: Guiding Light
entries: You are accustomed to the longest days and the longest nights. At 10th level, you gain resistance to radiant and cold damage. In addition you always know which way is north and cannot get lost.

subclassFeature.name: Boreal Danger
entries: At 14th level, you are ephemeral like the aurora. While you are using your Embodiment of the Frozen Light feature, you can choose to use your movement speed by teleporting instead of walking.
In addition if you roll initiative and have exhausted all uses of Mesmerising Light, you regain one use of that feature.

subclassFeature.name: Frost Wolf
entries: {@note The blizzard subsides temporarly, letting the citizens gaze in awe, as two men stand the middle of the frozen fields, unbothered The winds come back howling, everyone is looking for protection from this unyielding frost. Yet, there they remain, their hunt must continue.}

Frost wolves are said to herald from the deep north, where freezing temperatures are an everyday occurence, and nature seems hell-bent on ending all life. They have learned to harness the power of this unending winter, and their fighting style mimics the predatory animals that thrive in this environment. Little else is known about these warriors.

subclassFeature.name: Keen Senses
entries: At 3rd level your senses begin to sharpen, you gain proficiency in either {@skill Survival} or {@skill perception}.

subclassFeature.name: Winter Steel
entries: Winter flows in you, allowing you to empower your weapons momentarily. At 3rd level, as a bonus action you can empower one of your melee weapons with frost. Until the end of your turn, melee weapon attacks with that weapon deal an additional {@dice 1d4} cold damage. In addition everytime you wound creatures with this cold damage their movement speed is reduced by 5ft, to a minimum of 0, until the start of your next turn, as ice covers and slows them.

subclassFeature.name: Beastly Intuition
entries: At 7th level, your animalistic instincts sharpen, you can add your proficiency bonus to your initiative checks. In addition you gain resistance to cold damage.

subclassFeature.name: Pack Tactics
entries: At level 10, you know how to work with your pack. You have advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of your allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't incapacitated.

subclassFeature.name: Frozen Blood
entries: At 15th level, you are the embodimement of the unending winter. You become immune to cold damage. In addition the ground in a 10-foot radius around you is icy and is difficult terrain for creatures other than you. The radius moves with you, and doens't affect allies. You can activate this effect at will (no action required).

subclassFeature.name: Blizzard Strike
entries: At 18th level ou can hurl yourself like the blizzard. As an action you rush forward and strike. Choose a creature within 30ft of you, it must make a Dexterity saving throw (DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constituion modifier) or be hit by the full force of your strike. On a failure, a creature takes {@dice 6d8} bludgeoning damage and {@dice 6d8} cold damage and is knocked prone. On a success, a creature takes half as much damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}. You then appear within 5ft of the creature.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Light Bearer
entries: {@note They bring light in a frozen world of darkness, and never let it go.}

subclassFeature.name: Body of Light
entries: Beginning at 3rd, you are able to use your own body to pave the way in darkness. On your turn, you can illuminate your body (no action required), shedding bright light in a 10ft radius, and dim light 10ft beyond that. This light illuminates any darkness.

subclassFeature.name: Bright Shield
entries: At 3rd level, you have learned to protect your allies wielding light itself. When a friendly creature you can see is hit by an attack, you can use your reaction to defend them with a shield of light. The target gains a +3 bonus to their AC until the beginning of your next turn, including against the triggering attack. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency modifier per short rest.

subclassFeature.name: Light of Hope
entries: At 3rd level, you know the {@spell light} cantrip and you can cast it without verbal or material components. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for this spell Additionally, if you target a weapon you're wielding with this cantrip, the weapon's damage becomes radiant for the duration of the spell or until you let go of it.

subclassFeature.name: Inescapable Dawn
entries: At 7th level you cannot be {@condition blinded}.

In addition, You can cast the {@spell daylight} spell a number of times per long rest equal to your proficiency bonus. Constitution is your spell casting modifier for this spell When you cast the spell with this ability, any creature of your choice in the radius of the light must make a Constitution saving throw when the spell is casted initially, or be {@condition blinded} for 1 minute. An affected creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of their turn.

subclassFeature.name: Shining Heart
entries: Beginning at level 10, the light that burns inside of you shelters you and others. You gain resistance to radiant and fire damage. As an action you can touch an ally and give them these resistances for 1 minute, it ends early if you use this ability on another creature.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Body of Light
entries: Starting at 15th level your Body of Light feature dispels any magical darkness that comes in contact with the light, without requiring ability checks. In addition if an ally begins their turn in contact with the light you shed, they gain a number of temporary Hit point equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Blazing Sun
entries: At 18th level you unleash the light in your body. You can cast the {@spell sunburst} spell once per short rest, Constitution is your spell casting modifier for the spell

subclassFeature.name: Way of Frost
entries: {@note Most fear the cold and its embrace, the numbness that overtakes you, the lethargy that sweeps over. The ice freezing you to the bones, like knives digging in your flesh.}

Monks of the Way of the Frost are the opposite, trained in monasteries in the heart of the arctic weather, they learn to focus their ki to harness the powers of frost, pushing far beyond their limitations to reach mastery over this element. They can freeze anything and shatter their opponents' will Even their breath seems to condense as they breathe. It is said that their body creates this absolute zero cold, as they permanently radiate this freezing aura.
Many of the monk abilities can be reflavored to fit this ice theme. Stunning strike could trap the enemy in ice, and the extra movement could be seen as you sliding on ice, etc...

subclassFeature.name: Frost Weaponry
entries: Starting at 3rd level, your training in below zero temperatures has given you new ways to spend your ki points:

entries.name: Frost Weapons
entries: You are able to create 2 one-handed weapons made of ice, one in each hand, using the ambient humidity. You can spend 1 ki points to create them as a bonus action. The created weapons have the Light, Range (20/60), Thrown properties and count as monk weapons. They deal your martial hit die cold damage + Dex mod + Wis mod on a hit, and last until the end of your next turn.

entries.name: Frost Shards
entries: You can create a flurry of ice shards that erupt from your hand like a blizzard. As an action, you can spend 2 ki point, and all creatures within a 15ft cone from you must make a Dex Saving throw or take {@dice 4d4} cold damage and have their movement reduced by half, the ice encasing them. On a success they only take half damage and their movement remains unaffected.
The damage for this ability increases by {@dice 2d4} for each additionnal 1 ki point spent to use it.

subclassFeature.name: Frost Body
entries: At 3rd level, when an attack is made against you, you can use your reaction to cover your body with a thick layer of ice, gaining +3 to your AC until the start of your next turn. You * can use this ability a number of times equal to 1 + Wisdom Modifier (minimum of 1) per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Chill and Shivers
entries: Starting at 3rd level, your brutal training and way of life makes you scary to the common folk, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Intimidation} skill. If you're already proficient, your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make using that skill instead.
In addition, as an action you can choose an area of water that you can see within 60ft and that fits within a 5-foot cube, you can freeze it, shatter it, and levitate the ice.

subclassFeature.name: Absolute Zero
entries: At 6th level, your ability to harness the cold becomes second nature, you gain resistance to cold damage.

subclassFeature.name: Frozen Clone
entries: At 6th level, when you use your frost body ability and block a hit with it, you can instead teleport, leaving an ice clone of yourself that takes the hit. You teleport 5ft behind the attacker and can make a single weapon attack.

subclassFeature.name: Unyielding Blizzard
entries: Starting at level 11, when you use your flurry of blows ability while equipped with your Frost Weapons, you can choose to attack with them instead of making unarmed strikes.
In addition any damage you deal that does cold damage ignores resistance to cold.

subclassFeature.name: Arctic Pressure
entries: At 17th level, you can spend an action to push your ice powers to their limit. As a bonus action you can choose a number of creature that you can see within 120ft around you equal to 1 + Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1) and expose their weakness. For the next minute, all cold damage that you deal is doubled against those creatures.
This ability requires you to maintain concentration, as you would for a spell.

This power takes a toll on your body, the first time you use it you suffer no adverse effect. If you use this feature again before you finish a long rest, you take {@dice 4d12} cold damage immediately. Each time you use this feature again before finishing a long rest, the cold damage increases by {@dice 2d12}. This damage ignores resistance and immunity.

subclassFeature.name: Tenets of Storms
entries: The power of the storm is thine to command, now hear thy tenets, oh warrior of thunder.

entries.name: Gale
entries: You have a duty to the winds and the sky. Though you may call the lands your home, the winds will ever call you to serve your duty as far as the sky's reach. Do not hesitate, but serve their bidding with joy.

entries.name: Thunder
entries: Be the voice for the voiceless. Speak for the downtrodden and the oppressed.

entries.name: Lightning
entries: When the corruption of the earth grows, the burden of honor will fall to thee. You will be the guardian of the realms of men and the vanguard of the realms of the divine.

entries.name: Downpour
entries: In word, deed, and action, cultivate the joy of life in the world. When the wars are over and the evils are done, light and laughter will flourish once more. Prepare the world for this time.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed.

entries.caption: Oath of Storms Spells
rows: {@spell cone of cold}, {@spell steel wind strike|xge}

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Summon the Storm
entries: You present your holy symbol as an action. In the next minute, the area in a 2 mile radius centered on you when you cast this channel divinity becomes covered by a violent storm. All creatures directly under that storm are considered lightly obscured. The storm vanishes after {@dice 1d4} hours.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Thunderous Armament
entries: As an action you present your holy symbol One melee weapon of your choice becomes infused with the energy of the storm for 1 minute. Your hits deal an additional amount of thunder damage equal to your charisma modifier and once per turn when you hit a creature that is large or smaller with that weapon you can choose to push it back 10ft.
At 11th level you can push back creatures that are Huge or smaller, and at 17th level creatures that are Gargantuan or smaller.

subclassFeature.name: Aura of the Storm
entries: At  7th  level  your  aura  in  a  10ft  radius  around  you  unleashes the fury of the storm, you inactivate this aura at will.

items: The attack rolls of enemy ranged attacks have disadvantage if they pass in or out of the wind.
It extinguishes unprotected flames in its area that are torch-sized or smaller.
It hedges out vapor, gas, and fog that can be dispersed by strong wind.

subclassFeature.name: Roaring Storm
entries: At 15th level, as a reaction to an enemy attacking an ally within your aura. You can teleport in a flash exchanging position between yourself and your ally, making you the new target. The attacker takes {@dice 2d6} + your charisma modifier thunder damage, as you appear in a thunderous explosion.

subclassFeature.name: Avatar of the Storm
entries: Beginning at 20th level, as an action you embody the power of the God of Thunder. You gain the following benefits for 1 minute:

items: Flying speed of 60 ft

As a bonus action you can teleport up to 30ft in a flash of lightning, all creatures within a 10ft radius of the point you reappear in must succeed on a Dexterity Saving throw or take {@dice 5d8} lightning damage, or half as much on a success.
Immunity to thunder and lightning damage.

subclassFeature.name: Oath of the Dawn
entries: This oath originated in the cities of the North, where the sun was scarce, and sacred The power of the light is a holy one, bestowed only upon the purest of heroes. Those that embrace this oath stand as a bulwark against the darkness.

entries.name: Light of Hope
entries: The night can be dark and full of horrors. You will bring the light even in the darkest despair, no matter the cost to yourself.

entries.name: Incandescent Purity
entries: Darkness tries to devour the world, but the light shall face it and cleanse it. Purify those that lost their ways.

entries.name: Radiant Humanity
entries: Civilisation has brought fire and light to the world, illuminating it. Do your utmost to keep it prosper and bright.

subclassFeature.name: Oath Spells
entries: You gain oath spells at the paladin levels listed.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Wings of Light
entries: As a bonus action, light emblazons you. A pair of wings of light sprout on your back, you gain a flying speed of 40ft for 1 minute. At 11th level the duration increases to 10 minutes, at 18th level it increases to one hour.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Bright Hope
entries: As a reaction to you or allies making a saving throw, you can present your holy symbol You and allies within 30ft of you gain a bonus to the saving throw equal to twice your charisma modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Radiant Aura
entries: The light held within your heart shines through. At 7th level, at will, a 10ft radius around you is filled with bright light, magical darkness that comes in contact with it is automatically dispelled.

In addition enemies that start their turn in your aura or enter it for the first time on their turn must make a Dexterity saving throw or shed dim light in a 10ft radius. Any Attack roll against an affected creature has advantage if the attacker can see it, and the affected creature or object can't benefit from being Invisible.
At 18th level the range of this aura increases to 30ft.

subclassFeature.name: Retributive Light
entries: At 15th level, all creatures of your choice that start their turn in your aura, or enter it for the first time on their turn, take radiant damage equal to your charisma modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Avatar of the Dawn
entries: Beginning at 20th level, as a bonus action you embody the power of the holy light. You gain the following benefits for 1 minute:

items: Enemies within your aura must make a Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded} for the duration of the transformation, can repeat the save.
Your attacks deal an extra {@dice 2d8} radiant damage, and you score critical hits on a roll of 19 or 20.
You are immune to radiant and necrotic damage.

entries: This effect ends early if you are incapacitated or die. You can use this feature once per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Expended Spell List
entries: The Storm lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Sapping Mark
entries: At level 3, When you cast the spell {@spell hunter's mark} you don't need to concentrate on it. In addition the damage dealt by the spell prevents healing, when you damage a creature on your turn under the effect of your mark, it cannot regain hit points until the beginning of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Frozen Winds
entries: Also at level 3, as a bonus action, you can choose to turn yourself into a frozen wind until the end of your turn. When you move in this form you don't trigger Attacks of Opportunity, you have a flying speed equal to your walking speed and can move through spaces as small as 1 inch without squeezing.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to 1 + your Wisdom Modifier (minimum of 1) per short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Animalistic Toughness
entries: Your body is as resilient as those of beasts. Starting at level 7 you gain proficiency in Constitution saving throws (or your choice of Dexterity or Strength saving throws if you are already proficient).

subclassFeature.name: Prowler's Intuition
entries: Starting at level 11, you become more in tune with your prowler's instincts. Your walking speed increases by 5ft.In addition, while transformed in the form granted by your Frozen Wind feature, your attacks deal an additional {@dice 1d8} cold damage. That damage increases to {@dice 2d8} at level 17.

subclassFeature.name: Beastly Instinct
entries: At level 15, as a reaction to taking damage you can instinctively dodge out of the way, leaving a trail of frost behind you. You ignore the damage from the triggering attack and can move up to half your walking speed without triggering attacks of opportunity.
Once you used this ability a number of times equal to 1 + your Wisdom Modifier, you can't use it again until you take a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Stormheart
entries: {@note Be still The wind screams more than howls. Rain falls as stones. The trees they bend and moan in wrath enough to scare the Gods, branches torn like paper limbs. This storm, . more wicked than any in living memory, is watched through debris that tumbles, heavy like bullets, destroying anything and everything, avenging the forgotten.}

Stormhearts are rogue trained in the highest of secrecy. Elite warriors of the tribes they serve, they bend lightning and use it to relentlessly pursue opponents. Hard to pin down they present as formidable foes in the tides of war.

subclassFeature.name: Lightning Conduit
entries: At level 3, you are swift as the lightning, your walking speed increases by 5ft, and another additional 5ft at level 8 and 16.

In addition, when you use your Sneak Attack, you can choose to turn the Sneak Attack damage into lightning damage. If you do so, the target cannot use reactions until the start of your next turn. You can use this feature a number of times equal to 1 + your Constitution modifier per long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Storm's Reprisal
entries: Starting at 3rd level you have learned to create bolts of lightning from your body. Immediately after you use your Cunning Action, you can make a ranged spell attack against a creature within 30 feet of you, provided you used the Attack Action and haven't used your Sneak Attack this turn. You are proficient with it, and you add your Dexterity modifier to its attack and damage rolls.

A creature hit by this attack takes lightning damage equal to half your Sneak Attack damage (roll and divide by 2). This uses your Sneak Attack for the turn. This ability can be used with the Lightning Conduit feature.

subclassFeature.name: Prophetic Tempest
entries: At 9th level, You can commune with the destructive element that is the Storm, learning about the path ahead. When you do so, you cast the {@spell divination} spell, without using a spell slot or material components. Constitution is your spellcasting ability for this spell
Communing in this way invigorates you. When the spell ends you gain temporary Hit Points equal to twice your Constitution Modifier.
After you cast the spell with this feature, you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Cloudburst
entries: At 13th level, right after damaging a creature with your Sneak Attack feature, you can teleport up to 30 feet.
In addition when you kill a creature of CR1 or higher, you regain one use of your Lightning Conduit feature.

subclassFeature.name: Stormborn
entries: Lightning envelops your body. At 17th level, you have a flying speed equal to your current walking speed whenever you are not underground or indoors.

subclassFeature.name: Snow Soul
entries: {@note Snow danced in the light, a choreographed ballet conducted by the gentle wind As Ava watched her eyes grew that tiny bit wider, as open as her kid sister when she saw the street had become as a fresh new page awaiting her playful feet and mittened hands.}

It is not known exactly what gave birth to snow soul sorcerers, all is known is that they are blessed with a natural affinity for the cold. The soft touch of the snow allows them to play tricks on the mind. While many use this power for good, more than one used these powers for evil ends.

subclassFeature.name: Expended Spell List
entries: At certain levels, your Snow Soul Sorcerer learns new spells from the Snow Soul Table, these spells don't count against the maximum number of spells your character can learn.

subclassFeature.name: Ephemeral Snow
entries: Your magic is cold, soft and fleeting like snow. At 1st level, you learn the {@spell ray of frost} cantrip, it doesn't count against the number of cantrips you can know.
In addition you gain resistance to cold damage, and at 3rd level you gain the Subtle Spell metamagic option, it doesn't count against the maximum number of metamagic options you can pick.

subclassFeature.name: Irresistible Blizzard
entries: Upon reaching 6th level, when you cast a spell that deals cold damage or that belongs to the enchantment spell school, you can spend 1 sorcery point to have the spell casted as if using one spell slot level higher.

subclassFeature.name: Frozen Memories
entries: Beginning at 14th level, you gain immunity to cold damage.
In addition, when a creature recovers from being charmed by you, it has no memory of what happened during the time it was charmed.

subclassFeature.name: Implacable Winter
entries: As a bonus action, you can embody the harshness on the north for one minute. While this effect is active you gain the following benefits:

items: When you roll damage for a spell you cast that deals cold damage, you can treat any 1, 2 or 3 on a damage die as a 4.
Targets of your enchantment spells have disadvantage on the save, and are affected even if they are immune to the charmed condition.

entries: Once you use this ability you can't use it again until you complete a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Expended Spell List
entries: The Storm lets you choose from an expanded list of spells 1 when you learn a warlock spell The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Shattering Blast
entries: At 1st level you can choose to unleash the energy of the storm, as an action, all creature in a 15ft cone in front of you must succeed on a Dexterity Saving throw or take {@dice 1d10} force damage.
The damage of this ability increases as you reach higher 4 levels: {@dice 3d10} at 5th level {@dice 5d10} at 11th level {@dice 7d10} at 17th level

subclassFeature.name: Storm Body
entries: Beginning at 6th level once per short rest, as a bonus action, you can choose to let the storm infuse your body. Your body becomes ephemeral as if made of thunderclouds. You gain the following benefits for one minute:

items: Resistance to slashing, piercing, bludgeoning damage from non-magical weapons.
A hover speed equal to your walking speed.
Temporary HP equal to twice your Charisma Modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Lightning Reflexes
entries: At 10th level Your body is electric, enhancing your reflexes. You can add your Charisma modifier to your Initiative checks and Acrobatic checks.
In addition you gain resistance to lightning damage.

subclassFeature.name: Retaliating Thunder
entries: Starting at 14th level when a creature should make your health drop to 0 hit points or below, you can instead choose to let the Storm cover and protect you. You fall to a number of hit points equal to your level and immediately enter your Storm Body form, it doesn't count against your normal amount of uses. In addition the creature that attacked you takes lightning damage equal to your level and is incapacitated until the start of your next turn as a bolt of roaring lightning strikes it.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Tri-Caster
entries: {@note How does magic work ? Rule of 3, clearly.}
{@bold -Balthibab, Grand Tricaster Wizard}

These wizards are empowered by ancient magic, allowing them to use the rule of 3 to improve their casting, and shatter the battlefield The only reason this school of magic exists in the first place is thanks to deep dives under the earth where ncient knowledge was recovered and studied.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane of the Triad
entries: At 2nd level, every third spell that you cast, using a spell slot of 1st level or higher, within the same hour, is considered as casted with a spell slot of one level higher (to a maximum of a 9th level spell slot).

subclassFeature.name: Tertiary Knowledge
entries: Also at 2nd level, your knowledge is magically enhanced You can add a +3 bonus to your arcana, history and religion checks.

subclassFeature.name: Third Instinct
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you can empower your reflexes magically. When initiative is being rolled after your roll but before knowing the initiative order, you can, as a reaction, consume a third level spell slot to put yourself third in the initiative order.

subclassFeature.name: Magic Absorption
entries: At level 10, when you take damage from a spell or magical effect,  you  can  absorb  the  energy  from  the  magic  to  refuel your own reserve. As a reaction you ignore a third of the damage you received (rounded up), and regain some of your expended spell slots. The spell slots can have a combined level that is equal to or less than a third of your wizard level (rounded up).
Once you used this ability you can't use it again until you complete a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Unleashed Arcane
entries: At 14th level: You gain the ability to unleash your powers. You consume your action, reaction, bonus action to cast 3 spells at the same time with the same action. Each of these spells must use a maximum of a 3rd level spell slot, and only one of those spells can require concentration. After using this ability, you can only cast cantrips on your next turn.
You can use this ability once every 3 days.

item.name: Immovable Boots
entries: These simple iron shoes have a button on the side of the heel You can use a reaction to click the heels together and press the button, which causes the shoes to become magically fixed in place. Until you or another creature uses a bonus action or reaction to press the button again, the shoes don't move, even if they are defying gravity. The shoes can hold up to 8,000 pounds of weight. More weight causes the shoes to deactivate and fall A creature can use an action to make a DC 30 Strength check, moving the fixed shoes up to 10 feet on a success.

item.name: Mjölnir
entries: You gain a +3 bonus to Attack and Damage rolls made with this magic weapon. While attuned it has the Thrown property with a normal range of 20 feet and a long range of 60 feet, and returns to your hand after every hit.

This weapons deal an extra {@dice 1d8} bludgeoning damage to giants. When you score a critical hit against a Giant using this weapon they instantly die. A Giant is immune to this effect if it has legendary actions, in which case it takes an extra 6d8 bludgeoning damage.
You can cast the {@spell ceremony} spell at will using this weapon, ignoring the material components and using the warhammer instead.

This weapon holds 5 charges. While holding this warhammer, you can use an action to expend 1 or more of its Charges to cast one of the following spells from it, using a DC 17: {@spell Lightning bolt} (1 charge); {@spell Chain lightning} (3 charges); {@spell Storm of vengeance} (5 Charges).
Mjolnir regains {@dice 1d4 + 1} charges daily at dawn.
item.reqAttune: by a creature with a Strength score of 20 or above

item.name: Crown of Thorns
entries: This amalgamation of thorns is formed in the shape of a crown to wear on one's head, it is said to have belonged to a martyr of old.
While attuned to this item, the user gains a +2 bonus to spell attack rolls and saving throws.

In addition, when casting a spell that deals damage of 1st level or higher, the user can take an amount of damage equal to the spell level in piercing damage (this damage ignores resistance and immunities), as the thorns dig in the flesh. When doing so they can transform the damage type of the spell to radiant.

If an Evil creature attunes to the crown, they take {@dice 5d10} radiant damage and {@damage 5d10} piercing damage every hour, as the crown constricts their head A creature killed in this fashion is turned to ash.
If a Neutral creature attunes to the crown, they don't gain any of the benefits from the crown, as it remains inert.
item.reqAttune: by a creature that can cast a spell of 1st level or higher

item.name: Corrupted Crown of Thorns
entries: This amalgamation of thorns is formed in the shape of a crown to wear on one's head, it is said to have belonged to a martyr of old. Demonic energy has touched the blood on the crown.
While attuned to this item, the user gains a +2 bonus to spell attack rolls and saving throws.

In addition, when casting a spell that deals damage of 1st level or higher, the user can take an amount of damage equal to the spell level in piercing damage (this damage ignores resistance and immunities), as the thorns dig in the flesh. When doing so they can transform the damage type of the spell to necrotic.
If a non Evil creature tries to attune to the crown their mind slowly fills with evil thoughts. After {@dice 1d10} days attuned to the crown, that creature's alignment will change to Evil
item.reqAttune: by a creature that can cast a spell of 1st level or higher

item.name: Justice of the Gods
entries: The divinity tattoed on your skin reduces your opponents to ash. As an action, you can force your tattoo to come to life. Divine lightning falls from the heavens. All creatures of your choice within 30 feet of you must succeed a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw or take {@dice 3d8} radiant damage, and {@dice 3d8} lightning damage, or half as much on a success. On a failure, the next attack roll made against each separate creature has advantage, thanks to the divine light illuminating the target.
You can use this tattoo twice per long rest.

item.name: Spark of the Ice Phoenix
entries: The entity tattoed on your skin grants you a sliver of its power. As a bonus action you can activate the tattoo, that bathes you in its frozen aura for 1 minute. While it is active the cold damage you deal ignore resistance and immunity.

In addition, if you should fall to 0 HP while this tattoo is active, you instead fall to a number of HP equal to twice your level, and the creature that damaged you takes cold damage equal to your level. After this the tattoo inactivates itself.
You can use this tattoo twice per long rest.

item.name: Call to the Sky
entries: As a bonus action, you can unfurl the wing tattoos on your back. A mighty wind swirls around you and lifts you 60 feet into the air, or as high as you can go before reaching a ceiling where you remain. While held aloft you are considered hovering and do not have a flying speed.

Due to the soaring winds ranged attacks have disadvantage against you, you have advantage on Dexterity savnig throws and do not trigger attacks opportunity. Attacks made while aloft are made with advantage and deal an additionnal amount of damage equal to your sneak attack damage.

This lasts until the beginning of your next turn, where you gently lower to the ground and land without taking damage. You can choose any unoccupied space within 20ft of your original location to land at.
You can use the tattoo three times per long rest.
item.reqAttune: by a creature with atleast 10 levels in the Rogue class

item.name: Bulwark of the Earth
entries: The Stone Golem tattoo on your chest protects you. Whenever you take damage, such as from an attack, you may use your reaction to become immune to the triggering damage. A barrier of stone forms around your body, protecting you. You can activate this tattoo only before knowing the amount of damage taken.
You can use this tattoo twice per long rest.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The wolf has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The wolf has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the wolf's allies is within 5 ft. of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bladewolf makes two greatsword attacks.

action.name: Greatsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft, one target. Hit 10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) slashing damage.

action.name: Sword Spin {@recharge 5}
entries: Each creature of the bladewolf's choice that is within 5 feet of the bladewolf must pass a {@dc 13} Dexterity saving throw or take 17 ({@dice 4d6 * 3}) slashing damage and be knocked {@condition prone} on a failure, or take half as much damage and not be knocked {@condition prone} on a success. The bladewolf can then move without triggering attacks of opportunity.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The bladewolf adds 2 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the bladewolf must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

A swift strike, a scream of pain, blood stains in the forest. Bladewolves show no mercy to their prey, no matter how big, the ogre realises this too late. He swings again, missing, retaliation, another cut appears on his chest, next to him his dead companion, fallen under the blows of the pack. He fights to no avail He lost his lifelong companion, and soon after, his life.

entries.name: Appearance
entries: Bigger than an average wolf, bladewolves always carry around a sword with them, using it in their hunts. Two kind are known to exist, the forest dwelling bladewolf, and the artic bladewolf, bigger and fiercer, hardened by the unforgiving cold environment. When the two meet, the arctic predator usually comes out on top, and becomes the new leader of the pack.

entries.name: Cunning Beasts
entries: Pack hunters at their very core, they will stealth through forest hunting for their prey, striking at the opportune moment. They surround their prey, leaving no room for escape, and begin the slaughter.
If they see the situation slipping away from their control, they will retreat with their incredibly swift speed, coming back to hunt another day.

entries.name: Adepts of the sword
entries: How do they acquire their weapons ? No one knows for sure, but it is thought that they come from the bodies of adventurers that they have killed Another theory is that the weapons are given by the parents.

There has been sighting of a form of training between members of a pack. This could explain why they handle their weapon with an ease similar to that of a fine swordsman. Unsurprisingly their existence puzzles many sages in search of answers.
Frost Bladewolves often wield magical weapons inciting many adventurers to hunt them for the precious loot, few of these brave souls ever come back.

action.name: Sword Spin {@recharge 5}
entries: Each creature of the frost bladewolf's choice that is within 5 feet of the frost bladewolf must pass a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take 18 ({@damage 4d6 + 4}) slashing damage and 9 ({@dice 2d8}) and be knocked {@condition prone} on a failure, or take half as much damage and not be knocked {@condition prone} on a success. The frost bladewolf can then move without triggering attacks of opportunity.

immune.note: from  nonmagical  weapons  that  aren't  silvered

trait.name: Trapped Shapechanger
entries: The failed storm conduit werewolf cannot use its action to polymorph back into its true form, which is humanoid. It reverts to its true form if it dies. Its statistics are the same in each form. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The failed storm conduit werewolf has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks  that rely  on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Reckless Overcharge (Recharges on a Short or Long Rest)
entries: The failed storm conduit werewolf infuses itself with electric energy that he can't control. While this effect is active, for 1 minute, it can use a bonus action on each of its turn to teleport up to 10ft. In addition the first creature that damages it with a Melee Attack during the round takes 10 ({@damage 4d4}) lightning damage and it takes half of that damage, as the electricity jolts.
Right after the effect ends, it takes {@damage 2d8} lightning damage and is {@condition stunned} until the beginning of its next turn, as the electricity escapes its body.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The  failed  storm  conduit  werewolf  makes  two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft, one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or take an additional 2 ({@damage 1d4}) lightning damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d4 + 2}) slashing damage.

A monstrous scream rattles the facility. 'Another Failure" mumbles the doctor, standing above the body of the werewolf, that just rejected the transplant. He turns towards one of the large glass tube holding his only success. "Why are you gathering all this lightning when the others can't..." The massive monster made of fur and steel, with electricity coursing through it and the device on its back, grins,.., before vanishing. The assistant watches in horror as a claw pierces through the chest of his mentor. The beast is free.

Storm Conduits are werewolves that have been experimented on. During times of war, governments wanted to create a more powerful militia. Werewolves due to their unique genetic lineup were the perfect test subject. They were hunted and captured. Cruel experiments lead to many failures, and a few success, creatures capable of vanishing, and striking like the lightning. Losing their humanity in the process.

entries.name: Freedom at any cost
entries: Storm conduits were captured, and the few that managed to escape swore to never be treated like a lab animal again. They will fight for their freedom, and the freedom of their own until the bitter end, using any amounts of dirty tactics to achieve their goal.

entries.name: Trapped in flesh
entries: Storm Conduits used to be able to revert back to their human form, but the experiments removed that ability from them. Shunning them forever from societies. They live in the far outskirts of civilisation, in small tribes.

entries.name: Doomed to death
entries: Storm conduit lost their freedom and their ability to transform in the experiments, but also their ability to reproduce. The tribes that live together know that they will all perish, even if a few of them are still looking around for a method to remove the device implanted in their body.

immune.note: from nonmagical weapons that aren't silvered

trait.name: Overcharge (Recharges on a Short or Long Rest)
entries: The storm conduit werewolf infuses itself with electric energy. While this effect is active, for 1 minute, it can use a bonus action on each of its turn to teleport up to 15ft, it has resistance against lightning and thunder damage. In addition when a creature within 5ft of it damages it, it can use its reaction to make a Claw Attack against that creature.
Right after the effect ends, it takes {@damage 2d8} lightning damage and is {@condition stunned} until the beginning of its next turn, as the electricity escapes its body.
